citations.narrative:
***While observing the fallow deer enclosure USDA observed two members of the public feeding and interacting with the
deer while inside the deer enclosure. USDA remained at the enclosure to observe the interaction for a period greater than
five minutes. During this time there were no employees present and none observed monitoring the interaction. In
addition, it was noted that the staff in the park were not readily identifiable. During public exhibition animals must be
handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public with sufficient barriers between the animals and
public. If staff is to be the barrier provided then they shall be monitoring the periods of interaction at all times. Correct by
March 3, 2023.

***The drainage in the Watusi, Scottish Highlander, elk, and camel pens is insufficient to rapidly eliminate excess water.
Large areas of mud with puddling of water were observed in areas that the animals would be required to walk through in
order to access food, water or shelter. Excessive exposure to wet, muddy ground can lead to hoof problems, lameness
and other illnesses. Adequate drainage or appropriate surfaces shall be provided to allow the animals to access food,
water and shelter without requiring them to walk through excessive mud. Correct by March 22, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Vice President.
Additional Inspectors:
Jeffrey Shepherd, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALISTEnd Section

narrative:
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
***While observing the fallow deer enclosure USDA observed two members of the public feeding and interacting with the 
deer while inside the deer enclosure. USDA remained at the enclosure to observe the interaction for a period greater than 
five minutes.  During this time there were no employees present and none observed monitoring the interaction.  In 
addition, it was noted that the staff in the park were not readily identifiable.  During public exhibition animals must be 
handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public with sufficient barriers between the animals and 
public.  If staff is to be the barrier provided then they shall be monitoring the periods of interaction at all times.  Correct by 
March 3, 2023. 
3.127(c) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
***The drainage in the Watusi, Scottish Highlander, elk, and camel pens is insufficient to rapidly eliminate excess water.  
Large areas of mud with puddling of water were observed in areas that the animals would be required to walk through in 
order to access food, water or shelter.  Excessive exposure to wet, muddy ground can lead to hoof problems, lameness 
and other  illnesses. Adequate drainage or appropriate surfaces shall be provided to allow the animals to access food, 
water and shelter without requiring them to walk through excessive mud.   Correct by March 22, 2023.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Vice President. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Jeffrey Shepherd, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALISTEnd Section

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
